content.text: Plot the graph of \(y / \text{cm}\) (\(y\)-axis) against \(x / \text{cm}\) (\(x\)-axis). You do not need to include \((0, 0)\) on your graph
Determine the gradient \(G\) of the graph. Show clearly on the graph how you obtained the necessary information
Calculate the weight \(W\) of the metre rule using the equation \(W = \frac{L}{G}\) , where \(L = 1.0 \text{N}\)
Describe briefly how you would determine the position of the centre of mass of the
Describe how you would modify the experiment if the centre of mass was at the \(49.7 \text{cm}\) mark
The calculation of \(W\) is based on the assumption that the centre of mass of the \(50.0 \text{cm}\) mark
An IGCSE student is determining the weight of a metre rule
Fig. 1.1 shows the apparatus
\(\mathbf{X}\) is a 1.0 N load

The student places the load \(\mathbf{X}\) on the rule so that its centre is at \(d = 5.0 \text{cm}\) from the zero end of the rule, as shown in Fig.1.1. He adjusts the position of the rule so that it is as near as possible to being balanced, with the 50.0 cm mark to the right of the pivot

He measures and records the distance \(x\) from the centre of the load \(\mathbf{X}\) to the pivot, and the distance \(y\) from the pivot to the 50.0 cm mark on the rule. He repeats the procedure using \(d\) values of 10.0 cm, 15.0 cm, 20.0 cm and 25.0 cm. The readings of \(d\), \(x\) and \(y\) are shown in Table 1.1
A student records the temperature \(\theta_{\mathrm{c}}\) of \(100\mathrm{cm}^3\) of cold water and the temperature \(100\mathrm{cm}^3\) of hot water
Write down the temperature \(\theta_{\mathrm{c}}\) shown on the thermometer in Fig. 2.1
\(\theta_{\mathrm{c}} =\)
The hot water is at a temperature \(\theta_{\mathrm{h}} = 86^{\circ}\mathrm{C}\)
Calculate \(\theta_{\mathrm{av}}\), the average of \(\theta_{\mathrm{c}}\) and \(\theta_{\mathrm{h}}\)
average \(\theta_{\mathrm{av}} =\)

The student adds \(100 \text{cm}^3\) of the hot water to the cold water. She records the temperature \(\theta_{\text{m}}\) of the mixture of hot and cold water, \(\theta_{\text{m}} = 48^\circ \text{C}\)
State two precautions (other than repeating the experiment) that the student could take to ensure the reliability of her value of the temperature \(\theta_{\mathrm{m}}\)

Suggest a practical reason in this experiment for the temperature of the mixture \(\theta_{\mathrm{m}}\) being different from the average value \(\theta_{\mathrm{av}}\), even when the student has taken the precautions you suggested in (c)
Suggest a modification to the experiment which should reduce the difference between \(\theta_{\mathrm{m}}\) and \(\theta_{\mathrm{av}}\)
The student decides to repeat the experiment to check the readings. Suggest one possible variable that she should keep constant
The IGCSE class is investigating temperature changes when cold water and hot water
Calculate \(I_{\mathrm{B}} + I_{\mathrm{C}}\)
State whether the experimental results support the theory. Justify your statement by reference to the readings
statement
justification

A student measures the current \(I_{\mathrm{A}}\) at the position \(\mathbf{A}\) shown by the ammeter, and then at positions \(\mathbf{B}\) ( \(I_{\mathrm{B}}\) ), \(\mathbf{C}\) ( \(I_{\mathrm{C}}\) ) and \(\mathbf{D}\) ( \(I_{\mathrm{D}}\) )
The readings are:
Theory suggests that \(I_{\mathrm{A}} = I_{\mathrm{B}} + I_{\mathrm{C}}\) and \(I_{\mathrm{D}} = I_{\mathrm{B}} + I_{\mathrm{C}}\)
The student suggests repeating the experiment to confirm her conclusion. She
variable resistor (rheostat) in series with the switch. State the purpose of the variable
On Fig. 3.1, draw in the voltmeter connected as described, using the standard symbol for a voltmeter
Write down the voltmeter reading shown on Fig. 3.2
Calculate the resistance \(R\) of the combination of the three resistors using the equation \(R = \frac{V}{I}\)
The student connects a voltmeter and records the potential difference \(V\) across the combination of the three resistors
The IGCSE class is investigating the current in resistors in a circuit
The circuit is shown in Fig. 3.1
Draw a normal to this line that passes through its centre. Label the normal \(\mathbf{NL}\). Label the point at which \(\mathbf{NL}\) crosses \(\mathbf{MR}\) with the letter \(\mathbf{B}\)

Draw a line \(8\mathrm{cm}\) long from \(\mathbf{B}\) at an angle of incidence \(i = 40^{\circ}\) to the normal and to the left of the normal. Label the end of this line \(\mathbf{A}\). Record the angle of the
in the first row of Table 4.1
The line \(\mathbf{MR}\) shows the position of a mirror
Draw the line joining the positions of \(\mathsf{P}_{2}\) and \(\mathsf{P}_{3}\). Continue the line until it meets the normal
Measure, and record in the first row of Table 4.1, the angle of reflection \(r\) between the normal and the line passing through \(\mathsf{P}_{2}\) and \(\mathsf{P}_{3}\)
Fig. 4.2 shows the mirror which is made of polished metal and has a vertical line drawn on it

The student places the mirror, with its reflecting face vertical, on \(\mathbf{MR}\). The lower end of the line on the mirror is at point \(\mathbf{B}\). He places a pin \(\mathsf{P}_{1}\) at \(\mathbf{A}\). He views the line on the mirror and the image of pin \(\mathsf{P}_{1}\) from the direction indicated by the eye in Fig. 4.1. He places two pins \(\mathsf{P}_{2}\) and \(\mathsf{P}_{3}\) some distance apart so that pins \(\mathsf{P}_{3}\) , \(\mathsf{P}_{2}\) , the image of \(\mathsf{P}_{1}\) , and the line on the mirror all appear exactly one behind the other. The positions of \(\mathsf{P}_{2}\) and \(\mathsf{P}_{3}\) are shown

The student draws a line parallel to \(\mathbf{MR}\) and \(2\mathrm{cm}\) above it. He places the mirror on this line and repeats the procedure without changing the position of pin \(\mathsf{P}_{1}\). His readings for \(i\) and \(r\) are shown in the table

In spite of carrying out this experiment with reasonable care, it is possible that the values of the angle of reflection \(r\) will not be exactly the same as the values obtained from theory. Suggest two possible causes of this inaccuracy
The student was asked to list precautions that should be taken with this experi
to obtain readings that are as accurate as possible. Table 4.2 shows the suggestio
Place a tick \((\checkmark)\) in the second column of the table next to each correctly suggest precaution
suggested precaution

table.html:
avoid parallax (line of sight) errors when taking readings with the protractor
carry out the experiment in a darkened room
draw the lines so that they are as thin as possible
keep room temperature constant
place pins P2 and P3 as far apart as possible
use only two or three significant figures for the final answers

Fig. 4.1 shows the student's ray trace sheet
Fig. 4.1
Suggest a suitable distance \(d\) for students to use when carrying out this experiment
Suggest a suitable instrument for measuring the distance \(d\)
Calculate the average value \(\nu_{\mathrm {av}}\) for the speed of sound from the results in the table. Show your working
The student has recorded the values for the speed of sound \(v\) to five significant
State whether this is a suitable number of significant figures for the speed of sound this experiment. Give a reason for your answer
statement
reason
The IGCSE class is carrying out an experiment to determine the speed of sound in a
Fig. 5.1 indicates the method used. The experiment is conducted outside the school building

Student A strikes a drum once as loudly as possible. Student B stands some distance away from student A and starts a stopwatch when she sees the drum being hit. She stops the stopwatch when she hears the sound. She records the time interval \(t\) in Table 5.1. The experiment is repeated several times. She calculates the speed of sound \(v\) and enters the values in the table
